questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following equations is used to calculate the equilibrium potential for an ion?
questions.explanation:
Equilibrium potential for an ion is calculated using the Nernst equation. When there is a concentration gradient for an ion across the membrane, the ion tends to diffuse 
down the concentration gradient. The electric potential that exactly opposes this net diffusion is 
called the equilibrium potential for that ion. This is calculated using the Nernst equation. 59 
Sold by @itachibot It is expressed as the potential inside the cell (intracellular potential relative to the extracellular 
potential). To calculate the value of the equilibrium potential: Note: In this formula, the choice of concentration of the ion placed in the numerator and 
denominator does not matter because the formula is only used to derive the numerical value and 
not the sign ( +/- ). Mathematically, log (100/10) = 1 and log (10/100) = - 1. Hence, changing the 
numerator and denominator only changes the sign and the numerical value remains the same. This equation is used only to derive the numerical value of the potential. It is NOT used to derive 
the sign/charge (+/-). The sign/charge is derived from logic: • In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater outside, then the + ion moves 
from outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively. Hence, the potential 
will be positive. • In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater inside, then the + ion moves from 
inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively (as + ion moves outside). 
Hence the potential will be negative. • In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater outside, then the - ion moves from 
outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively. Hence the potential will be 
negative. • In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater inside, then the - ion moves from 
inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively (as - ion moves outside). 
Hence the potential will be positive.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following is used to calculate the equilibrium potential for diffusion of multiple 
ions?
questions.explanation:
60 
Sold by @itachibot The Goldman equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential when the membrane is 
permeable to several different ions. Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation Here, • P= permeability of the membrane to each ion, and • C= concentrations of the respective ions on the inside (i) and outside (o) of the membrane. The Na+, K+ and Cl- are the most important ions involved in the development of membrane 
potentials in nerve fibres and muscle fibres.

questions.question: Question 3: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium explains the

options.a: Effect of one non-diffusible ion on the distribution of other non-diffusible ions
options.b: Effect of one permeant ion on the distribution of other permeant ions
options.c: Effect of a permeant ion on the distribution of nondiffusible ions
options.d: Effect of a non-diffusible ion on the distribution of permeant ions

questions.explanation:
Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium explains the effect of a non-diffusible ion on the distribution of 
permeant ions. Consider the situation depicted below, 61 
Sold by @itachibot The membrane is permeable to K+ and Cl-. However, it is impermeable to the proteins. The 
impermeable protein molecules hinder the movement of K+ (negative charge of the proteins 
holding back positive charge of the K+) and favor the movement of Cl- (like charges repel). 
According to the Gibbs-Donnan equation, at equilibrium, the concentration ratios of diffusible 
ions are equal across the membrane.

questions.question:
Question 4: Extracellular concentration of a positive ion (with valency = 1) is 100mmol/L and its 
intracellular concentration is 10mmol/L, the potential across the membrane using Nernst 
equation is (mV)
questions.explanation:
The potential of a positive ion across the membrane using Nernst equation is +60mV. 62 
Sold by @itachibot Where, z is valency in the formula. Deriving the numerical value: EMF = 61/1 *log 10/100 = 61 The choice of concentration of the ion placed in the numerator and denominator does not matter 
because the formula is only used to derive the numerical value and not the sign ( +/- ). 
Mathematically, log (100/10) = 1 and log (10/100) = - 1. Hence, changing the numerator and 
denominator only changes the sign and the numerical value remains the same. Deciding the sign/charge: A positive ion with greater concentration extracellularly will try to 
diffuse inside the cell. A positive intracellular potential is required to prevent this. Hence the 
sign/charge (potential) is positive (+). Hence, the potential across the membrane using the Nernst equation is +60mV (the closest 
answer chosen).

questions.question:
Question 5: Extracellular concentration of a negative ion (with valency = 1) is 10mmol/L and its 
intracellular concentration is 100mmol/L. The equilibrium potential for this ion using Nernst 
equation is (mV)
questions.explanation:
The equilibrium potential for this negative ion using the Nernst equation is +60mV. 63 
Sold by @itachibot Where, z is valency in the formula. Deriving the numerical value: EMF = 61/1 *log 100/10 = 61 Deciding the sign/charge: A negative ion with greater concentration intracellularly will try to 
diffuse outside the cell. A positive intracellular potential is required to prevent this. Hence, the 
potential is positive. Hence, the Nernst potential is +60mV (the closest answer chosen).

questions.question: Question 6: What is the Nernst potential for K+ in milivolt (mV)?
questions.explanation:
The Nernst potential for K+ is 90mV. Note: • For K+ ions, the concentration gradient is directed outward and the electrical gradient is 
directed inward. • In general, all excitable cell membranes at rest are maximally permeable to K+ and thus their 
RMP is close to equilibrium potential of K+ ion.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following ions have the highest positive equilibrium potential?
questions.explanation:
The ion with the highest positive equilibrium potential is Na+ that is +60mV. 64 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: The resting membrane potential of a nerve fibre depends on 56 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a nerve fibre depends on the diffusion of both K+ and 
Na+ and the Na+-K+ ATPase pump. The most predominant factor, however, is the diffusion of K+ ions. This is because, at rest, the 
permeability of the membrane of the nerve fibre to K+ ions is almost 100 times greater than that 
to Na+.

questions.question: Question 9: Resting membrane potential of the nerve fibre is equal to equilibrium potential of
questions.explanation:
Resting membrane potential of a nerve fiber is equal to the equilibrium potential of Cl- and is 
-‡0mV.

questions.question: Question 10: Driving force of a charged ion is

options.a: Measured membrane potential - calculated equilibrium potential
options.b: Measured membrane potential + calculated equilibrium potential
options.c: Calculated equilibrium potential - Measured membrane potential

questions.explanation:
The driving force on a charged ion is measured membrane potential (Em) - calculated equilibrium 
potential (Ex). Net driving force (mV) = Em - Ex where, Em = Actual membrane potential (mV) Ex = Equilibrium potential for X (mV) When the driving force is negative (i.e., Em is more negative than the ion’s equilibrium potential), 
then • A cation will enter the cell • An anion will leave the cell

questions.question:
Question 11: If the membrane potential of this cell is -80mV the driving force is greatest for which ion? 57 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The driving force is greatest for Ca2+. Net driving force is the difference between the membrane potential and the equilibrium potential 
for that particular ion. Hence Em - EX. Where: Em = Actual membrane potential (mV) = -80mV EX = Equilibrium potential for X (mV) For the respective ions: E Ca2+ = +120 ; Driving force = -80 – (120) = -200mV E Na+ = +60 ; Driving force= -80 – (60) =-1™0mV 65 
Sold by @itachibot E K+ = -90, Driving force = -80 – (-90) =10mV E Cl-= -‡0, Driving force = -80 – (-‡0) =-10mV Thus, Ca2+ will have the largest driving force and it will move inwards or into the cell.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following techniques is used to study the current flow across single ion channel?
questions.explanation:
The patch-clamp technique is used to record ion current flow through a single protein channel. In the patch-clamp experiment, a small pipette is carefully maneuvered to seal off a portion of a 
cell membrane. The pipette has an electrode bathed in an appropriate solution that allows for the 
recording of electrical changes through any pore in the membrane.

questions.question:
Question 13: What is the effect on the cellular membrane when the extracellular concentration of K+ is 
decreased?
questions.explanation:
When the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), there is increased 
negativity of RMP. RMP predominantly depends on the diffusion of K+ from inside to outside the cell. This diffusion 
depends on the concentration gradient with the inside of the cell having a larger concentration of 
K+ ions. When the extracellular concentration of K+ decreases, the concentration gradient for K+ 
rises. Therefore, more K+ ions diffuse out of the cell. This leaves the inside of the cell more 
negative relative to the extracellular space. This increases the negativity of the RMP, leaving the 
membrane hyperpolarised.

questions.question:
Question 14: X, ‘, ’ are three permeable ions. X = -50 and ‘ = -30. At RMP, if there is no net electrogenic 
transfer, what is the value of ’?
questions.explanation:
No net electro genic transfer at RMP means X + ‘ + ’ = 0 66 
Sold by @itachibot šince X = -50 and ‘ = -30, then ’ must be +80 since (-80 +80 = 0) 67
